His party, the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which opposed the card readers, labeled it a "huge national embarrassment." Inec chair Attahiru Jega emphasized that only a small portion of the 150,000 card readers nationwide malfunctioned. The vote was postponed by six weeks due to Boko Haram insurgency. original: Charles Mumbere, the king of Rwenzururu, is entitled to these privileges because he suffers from hypertension and diabetes, it added. But prison authorities say an outsider will not be allowed into the prison to prepare his meals. The king was arrested last month after a security force raid on his palace in western Uganda's Kasese district. More than 80 people were killed in the clashes. The 64-year-old monarch denies any involvement in violence. He was arrested with more than 150 people, including royal guards. His lawyer, Caleb Alaka, told the BBC he will ensure that prison officials comply with the court order. Mr Alaka said he initially thought there was a royal cook among those arrested but they had all "perished" during the raid on the palace. The monarch would accept a cook appointed by prison authorities, he added. Officials also said there were no plugs in the cells to power fridges, local media reports. But Mr Alaka told the BBC the

original: Masai Graham won with the gag: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The festival's best jokes were selected by a panel of 10 judges before being put to 2,000 people, who voted for their favourite. Tim Vine, Stewart Francis and Zoe Lyon have previously won the competition, run by TV channel Dave. Graham, from West Bromwich, claimed the victory after making the shortlist in both 2014 and 2015. He said "It's an incredible honour to land Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell came second in the poll, with the joke: "Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." Judges sat through an average of 60 different comedy performances and sifted through more than 3,600 minutes of material before selecting their favourite gags. In a bid to judge only the quality of the joke, the name of the comic or their show is not revealed during the voting process. Steve North, general manager of

original: Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan Byron Lewis took over the ceremonial role. The battalion's commanding officer said it would have been a first to have been presented leeks by the Queen. The cancellation by the Queen led to more sparse crowds watching the ceremony than had been anticipated. Speaking beforehand, commanding officer Rob Manuel said it had been "a bit of a surprise" when the announcement that the Queen would not be attending was made. However, he told BBC News: "We switched to plan B, and our thoughts and wishes are with her and we hope that she makes a speedy recovery. "The lord lieutenant has stepped into the breach. Today is going to run as per normal. "It would have certainly been a first for the queen to present leeks to 3rd Battalion, being a reserve battalion, especially for the chaps who have just come back from Afghanistan just before Christmas. "To have their leeks presented by the commander-in-chief is a really special day and really shows that the

Commanding officer Rob Manuel said the news was surprising but they switched to plan B and wished the Queen a speedy recovery. The lord lieutenant stepped in, and the event proceeded as planned. The presentation of leeks by the Queen to the 3rd Battalion, especially those recently returned from Afghanistan, would have been a unique honor.

original: The proposals are believed to include tougher English language requirements for students. Dominic Scott, head of the UK Council for International Student Affairs, said it would be a "nail in the coffin" for recruiting overseas students. The Home Office has argued there are no limits on numbers of genuine students. Universities have already been lobbying ministers to remove overseas students from migration targets - but the new English language proposals, if they were given the go-ahead, would mean even an higher threshold for entry. Universities argue that overseas students are increasingly important to the UK economy and that raising more barriers sends out a negative message in this competitive global market. Universities UK says overseas students are worth Â£7bn to the UK each year. Mr Scott, head of the advisory body on international students, described the revised language requirements as "pretty extreme". original: Mr Joshua told his congregation on Sunday that he "saw" a woman winning. After Donald Trump convincingly won Tuesday's vote, visitors to the preacher's Facebook page noticed the prophecy had been removed. The wealthy pastor is known as "the prophet" to his many followers. He is one of Nigeria's best-known and influential evangelists - and is popular across Africa, with many top politicians among his flock. The US election prediction was broadcast on Mr Joshua's TV channel Emmanuel TV, which an individual uploaded to YouTube. A section of that "prophecy" was posted on the preacher's Facebook page but is no longer available. "Ten days ago I saw the president of America with a narrow win... What I frankly saw was a woman," it said. TB Joshua has been trending on Twitter across Nigeria, Ghana and South Africa as people shared memes poking fun at his prediction. People have also taken to a Facebook entry he posted on Wednesday to complain. Clive Mashiri from South Africa asked: "Why was the prophecy deleted? If this was uttered by the man of God, why remove it?" Though some have defended

original: John McCormack drove for a further 30 miles in the articulated lorry after hitting the vehicle on the A9. Perth Sheriff Court was told there were three children in the car at the time of the incident. The 46-year-old was ordered to carry out 250 hours of unpaid work and banned from driving for two years. Prosecutor Rebecca Kynaston said motorists heading north near the House of Bruar shopping complex saw McCormack driving straight towards them. She said: "To their horror they saw the lorry coming south. He was on the wrong side of the road. "They managed to get off the road onto the verge. "The lorry missed them, but unfortunately it continued on and a couple with three children in their car weren't so lucky." Ms Kynaston said that the lorry hit the offside of the car and scraped along it. She said: "One might have hoped that would bring this to an end. The impact was forcible and bent the

original: Stephen Parnaby, Conservative leader of East Riding of Yorkshire Council, said the announcement was "great news for the town and the wider East Riding". The authority said it was spending about £100,000 on hosting the event. The organisers of last year's inaugural race said it brought £50m into the region's economy. The three-day event was launched by tourist body Welcome to Yorkshire after the county hosted the Tour de France Grand Depart in 2014. More than 1.2m people lined the 320-mile (515km) route. Mr Parnaby said last year's event had attracted thousands of spectators to the East Riding. "The council feels that the investment made by the authority, circa £100,000, to bring part of the race here is money well spent and will provide opportunities for local traders to capitalise on increased spending and help boost the East Riding economy," he said. Others in Beverley have also welcomed the race's arrival. Local amateur cyclist Ed Neilson said he hoped having the start of the race would encourage other cyclists to visit the town. original:
S4C gets most of its income from the licence fee and UK ministers have announced a major review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies has endorsed this initiative, suggesting the review will ensure a more transparent and accountable broadcasting service. 

The BBC currently operates under a Royal Charter, which is up for renewal every 10 years. This review will assess its public purposes, funding, and governance structure. Critics have raised concerns about the potential for political interference, however, Davies argued that the review will only enhance the BBC’s ability to deliver high-quality content to its viewers.

S4C, the Welsh-language public-service television channel, will also be impacted by this review. It heavily relies on the licence fee, receiving around 90% of its income from this source. The review will scrutinise the efficiency and effectiveness of this funding model, potentially impacting S4C's future operation. The results of the review will be awaited with interest by both viewers and broadcasters.

original: PC Frances Tilley admitted she had "destroyed her career" after evading payment for a journey between Bristol Temple Meads station and Castle Cary in Somerset last June. A disciplinary hearing at Northamptonshire Police headquarters heard she was less than two years into her job and was still on probation. She was dismissed for gross misconduct. The hearing at Wootton Hall heard Tilley travelled from Northampton to Castle Cary on 22 June last year. The officer, described as "diligent, professional and committed", was travelling with friends and did not buy a ticket for the final leg of her journey. Force solicitor Elizabeth Briggs said: "She travelled from Bristol to Westbury and onto Castle Cary. At that stage, she did not have a valid ticket to travel. "There were opportunities for her to purchase a ticket. "She said it was her intention to not pay a rail fare for that part of the journey." original: The charity wants 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by civil war to be resettled by the end of the year. Ahead of UN talks in Geneva on the crisis, it highlighted figures showing only 1.4% had been helped so far. Oxfam said UK plans to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 were "not good enough", but Britain says it is also focused on providing aid to people in the region. The UK's pledge of Â£2.3bn to help people affected by the humanitarian crisis caused by the civil war in Syria makes it the second largest bilateral donor in the world after the US. Oxfam says while Britain has been generous in providing financial aid for those displaced by Syria's civil war, it "can and should do more". It argues that countries with strong economies and developed infrastructures need to shoulder a greater responsibility towards refugees than nations such as Lebanon and Jordan, where thousands of Syrians are now based. The Geneva conference should, the UK-based charity added, result in "urgent solutions, offering people safe and legal routes to a welcome" in other countries.
variant_1: The charity aims for 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by the civil war to be resettled by year-end. Before UN talks in Geneva on the crisis, it pointed out that only 1.4% have been assisted so far. Oxfam criticized the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 as insufficient, though Britain emphasizes its aid efforts in the region. The UK has pledged Â£2.3bn to aid those affected by Syria's civil war, making it the world's second largest bilateral donor after the US. Oxfam acknowledges Britain's financial generosity but insists more can be done. It believes wealthy countries with developed infrastructures should bear more responsibility for refugees than Lebanon and Jordan, which host many Syrians. The UK charity hopes the Geneva conference will produce urgent solutions, providing safe and legal pathways for refugees to be welcomed elsewhere.

Severely felt was the absence of England opener Haseeb Hameed, dismissed by Sam Curran in an unexpected twist. 

Hameed's exit came as a blow to the visitors, reflecting in their performance and the resulting score. Curran's brilliant strategy and execution were hailed as the turning point of the game. His dismissal of Hameed set the stage for Footitt to demonstrate his exceptional bowling skills, leading to the loss of five wickets, a testament to the home team's prowess.

The match, well into its challenging phase, was characterized by strategic play and surprising upsets. High anticipation surrounds the post-lunch session, with all eyes on the visitors' batting line-up and whether they can recover from the morning setback.

original: As with last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 notified bands can march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast. They must do so to the sound of a single drum beat. This year all music must stop 43 metres away from the church so there is no music within earshot of it. A planned residents' protest has also been restricted to a maximum of 50 people at two locations. The Orange Order has said it is appalled by the determination. "The commission is now simply a mouthpiece for republican propaganda, allowing them to dictate the terms of when, how and where loyal order parades are held," it said. "The invented new criteria of banning music within 'earshot' of a place of worship not in use, is as mischievous as it is absurd, and clearly put in place to further censor Protestant heritage on the supposed

The Orange Order expressed outrage at this decision, stating the commission has become a mouthpiece for republican propaganda, dictating the terms of loyal order parades. original: In a statement, it said Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay would raise the issue at a major two-day Asia-Europe summit starting on Friday, attended by China's Premier Li Keqiang. A UN-backed tribunal ruled on Tuesday that there was no legal basis to China's claims in the South China Sea. China has vowed to ignore the ruling. It says the panel has no jurisdiction and its activities in the region will not be affected. The Asia-Europe Meeting Summit (Asem) in Ulaanbaatar in Mongolia on Friday and Saturday will be the first major multilateral diplomatic gathering since the 12 July ruling over the South China Sea. The summit will see 53 leaders from Asia and Europe attending, including from countries such as Vietnam and Malaysia which also claim territory in the region. It will also be the first meeting in which the new Philippine government of President Rodrigo Duterte will be represented on the world stage. The Department of Foreign Affairs said Mr Yasay,

original:
The party's election manifesto said a funding floor would only be provided after a referendum was called. The St David's Day Agreement had said the vote should be held before such a move could be made. The seeming inconsistency has sparked a fierce debate among political parties and citizens alike, questioning the party's commitment to financial transparency and accountability.

Critics suggest that the move is a strategic ploy for the party to gain a political advantage, while supporters argue that it is a necessary step toward ensuring the smooth allocation of resources. The decision has also raised questions about the party's adherence to the St David's Day Agreement, which many view as a cornerstone of political practice and a pillar of democratic engagement. 

The party, in response to the concerns raised, maintains its stance that this move is in line with its commitment to strengthen democracy and promote fairer distribution of resources. Despite the controversy, the party stands firm on its decision, stating that the referendum is not an obstacle, but a necessary democratic process.

original: The European Challenge Tour event will be part of a big week in the season with both the US PGA Championship and Women's British Open also taking place. Tournament ambassador Hoey expects several European Tour winners to be in the Galgorm field. They are set to come up against several up and coming stars of the future. "The NI Open will attract an even stronger field than in previous years," says five-time European Tour winner Hoey. "Especially because it has such a good place on the schedule." Hoey's fellow Irish European Tour winners Peter Lawrie, Damien McGrane and Simon Thornton are all expected to compete while Walker Cup hero from 2015, Ardglass man Cormac Sharvin, is also likely to tee up. While Rory McIlroy and the other stars of world golf will be in action at the US PGA at Baltursol, there is no other event on in Europe during Northern Ireland Open week which could convince a number of well-known players to make the trip to the Ballymena venue. Hoey says that many of his peers have already indicated that they intend to play at Galgorm. "Players want to compete at

original: The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates. A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who were elected as SNP MPs but now sit as independent members. Labour's executive is also expected to decide candidate selection, while some challengers have come forward for the Conservatives and Lib Dems already. The UK goes to the polls on 8 June after Prime Minister Theresa May announced plans for a snap election, subsequently endorsed by MPs by 552 votes to 13. Ms McGarry and Ms Thomson were the only two Scottish MPs to vote against the election, with SNP members abstaining. If they do not return, the SNP will need to find five candidates, including three for the seats the party did not win in 2015. A number of party activists have already announced their intention to bid for the SNP ticket in the Glasgow East and Edinburgh West seats formerly occupied by the two women. On Friday, the UK Labour party issued a call for prospective for parliamentary candidates over Twitter, inviting party members to apply with a deadline

Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their breakup. 

Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their break-up. The tragic incident, which took place around 11 PM on Sunday, has left the community in shock and mourning. 

Purdy, known for his bravery and sense of justice, had reportedly approached the man in an attempt to quell the tension that had been building since the break-up. Unfortunately, the confrontation escalated to a deadly turn, resulting in the fatal shooting of the young man. 

Local authorities are investigating the case rigorously, while the community rallies together in memory of Purdy. The alleged shooter, now identified as the ex-boyfriend, is in police custody awaiting trial. This tragic event highlights the escalating issue of gun violence and the urgent need for a solution. As the investigation unfolds, the community holds its breath, hoping for justice for Ben Purdy.

original: The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the internet news group the Daily Beast two years ago. The Daily Beast's founder, Tina Brown, said its site now had more than 15 million unique visitors a month, a 70% increase on last year. She said in a statement: "Exiting print is an extremely difficult moment for all of us who love the romance of print and the unique weekly camaraderie of those hectic hours before the close on Friday night. By Ben ThompsonBusiness reporter, New York In 1933, Newsweek hit the news stands - a weekly magazine covering global events. But much like the world it's reported on over the last 80 years, much has changed in the publishing world too. Not least how consumers get their news. The number of Newsweek subscribers has slumped from more than 3 million at its peak to 1.5 million today. Couple that with falling advertising revenues for traditional print media and it's led Newsweek to ditch its print edition altogether. Newsweek Global, the digital only version, will be available via

original: It means instead of people owning cars and bikes, one version of the future is we all hire transport to get around. This week we got another example of that in the capital when oBike launched. It is a company backed by considerable venture capital and it's putting hundreds of hire bikes on London's streets. The company aims to have thousands in the capital by the end of the summer, after already operating huge schemes in South East Asia. The big difference compared to the existing cycle hire scheme is the bikes have no docking stations. A locking rear brake means they can be left anywhere. Users access them via an app and you can find them as they have a GPS locator. There is a one-off Â£49 refundable deposit to be paid and then 50p per half-hour. More companies are set to follow. oBike says it is aiming to work in conjunction with the existing scheme and it

The child, who was under 13, needed medical treatment following the attack by Ajay Jetha last year. A probation report three months earlier had identified Jetha as a potential risk to minors but lamentably, authorities failed to act. 

The attack, which occurred in Leicester, sparked public outrage and demands for a review of the probation system. It was revealed that Jetha, a 35-year-old man with a history of violent behavior, was not properly monitored after the damning report.

Prosecutors say the victim was subjected to a terrifying ordeal that has left her traumatized. The attack became a watershed moment, prompting serious questions about the effectiveness of the probation service in predicting and preventing such horrifying incidents. 

Jetha has since been sentenced to 10 years in prison. Meanwhile, the victim's family, with the support of their local community, is calling for a complete overhaul of the probation system to ensure no other child falls through the cracks.

This impressive surge in revenue, up by 27% from €26.9bn (£22.6bn) in 2020, underlines the company's resilience in a challenging business environment. The growth was driven largely by robust demand for the company's innovative product line and its successful expansion into new international markets. 

While many businesses have struggled due to Covid-19 restrictions, the company pivoted effectively, capitalising on the surge in online shopping and remote work. The firm also managed to strengthen its supply chain, thereby ensuring uninterrupted service to its global customer base.

A public vote will decide the winner, which will then compete against trees from across the Continent for the title of European Tree of the Year. The online voting ends on 9 October. variant_1: The Woodland Trust charity is running a competition featuring 10 trees nominated by the public. A public vote will determine the winner, who will then compete against other European trees for the European Tree of the Year title. Online voting closes on 9 October. A panel of experts selected the finalists from 200 public nominations based on their stories. The winning tree will receive a £1,000 care grant, and any tree with over 1,000 votes will get £500. Among the nominees is the "Sycamore Gap" tree near Hadrian's Wall, famous for appearing with Kevin Costner in the 1991 film Robin Hood Prince of Thieves. Another finalist is a Sheffield tree threatened by a street improvement plan. Local campaigner Paul Selby, who nominated it, said that making the shortlist highlights its national significance.

original: Until now, Google Assistant had only been available on the firm's own Pixel phones. The service, like Siri on iPhones, allows users to interact with apps and ask questions. LG was one of the first smartphone makers to reveal it would feature the assistant on its new device, the G6. Google's update will starting rolling out this week to users with Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat installed. "With this update, hundreds of millions of Android users will now be able to try out the Google Assistant," said Gummi Hafsteinsson, product lead for Google Assistant, in a blog post. But other virtual assistants are out there. At the Mobile World Congress tech show in Barcelona, Lenovo Moto revealed that Amazon's Alexa assistant would be coming to the Moto Z phone. This will happen via an alternative back - known as a MotoMod - that Amazon will sell for the Moto Z later this year. And at the CES tech show in Las Vegas last month, Chinese

original: It means instead of people owning cars and bikes, one version of the future is we all hire transport to get around. This week we got another glimpse into this potential future with Uber announcing its expansion into the e-bike rental industry. The ride-hailing giant has acquired Jump, a startup that provides dockless electric bikes allowing users to pick up and drop off bikes anywhere in the city. This move is a strategic pivot for Uber, a company traditionally associated with private car services, showcasing their willingness to adapt to the changing landscape of urban transportation. As we move towards a more sustainable and interconnected world, shared modes of transport, including bike sharing systems like Jump, are increasingly viewed as a viable alternative to private vehicle ownership. While there are still kinks to iron out, such as regulation and infrastructure, this acquisition indicates we're one step closer to a future where personal vehicle ownership may not be the norm.

original: OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term
variant_1: OUP examined over 120,421 short stories written by children aged 5 to 13, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. They found that new technology is becoming central to children's lives, but the way they write about it is evolving rapidly. Words like email, mobile, and Facebook are declining, replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. The term television has been overtaken by phone. The report also highlights the rise of the hashtag # in children's sentences to add extra meaning or commentary, such as #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta from Oxford University Press noted this as a major change in 2015, with children expanding the hashtag's use beyond a prefix or search term.
variant_2: Oxford University Press analyzed more than 120,421 short stories from children aged five to thirteen submitted to the BBC's 500 Words contest. They observed that technology is increasingly central in kids' lives, but their writing about it is shifting quickly. Words like email, mobile, and Facebook are decreasing, replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. Television has been replaced by phone. The report also points out the new common use of the hashtag # at the end of sentences to add meaning or comments, e.g., #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta of OUP said this change in 2015 was significant, with children broadening the hashtag's use beyond just a prefix or search term.

Vineeta Gupta from OUP said this was a notable change in 2015, with children extending the hashtag's use beyond a simple prefix or search term.

original: The Black Caps, having been set a world record 504 to win, resumed on 142-3 and their challenge quickly folded. Brendon McCullum hit a run-a-ball 80 but the Kiwis were all out for 295. Spinner Nathan Lyon took 3-63 in the second innings, while Mitchell Starc, Josh Hazlewood and Mitchell Marsh claimed two wickets apiece. Australia's first innings 556-4 declared set them up for the victory and opener David Warner was named man of the match for his scores of 163 and 116. "I thought the first morning really set the tone for us with Joe Burns and Davy Warner batting so well," Australia captain Steve Smith said. "I thought the top order set the test match up for us. The partnerships that we had in that top three were crucial to our success." The second Test begins in Perth on Friday and the series concludes with the inaugural day-night Test in Adelaide. New Zealand now face a tough task

original:
Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. "We feel that Joe Root is the perfect choice to take over the reins from Alastair Cook," said the England Cricket Board (ECB) in a statement. Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as the new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. Cook's resignation marked the end of an era and the beginning of Root's leadership. 

Root, 30, is considered one of the best batsmen in the world, with a Test average of close to 50. His appointment reflects his consistent performance and the respect he commands within the squad. "We are confident that he will lead the team to new heights," the ECB statement added. Root will be the 80th man to lead England in a Test match when he takes charge for the first time this summer. His first series in charge will be against South Africa at home. Root's vice-captain will be Ben Stokes.

variant_6: With a Test average near 50, Joe Root has been named the new England Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned, marking a new leadership era.
variant_7: The ECB expressed confidence in Joe Root's ability to lead the England Test team after he was named captain succeeding Alastair Cook.
variant_8: Joe Root will become England's 80th Test captain, taking over from Alastair Cook, with his first series against South Africa at home this summer.
variant_9: Ben Stokes will serve as vice-captain under Joe Root, who has been appointed England's new Test captain after Alastair Cook's resignation.
variant_10: Alastair Cook's resignation ended his four-year captaincy, with Yorkshire batsman Joe Root stepping in as the new England Test captain.

original: Remus Hamza, 40, is alleged to have attacked the 20-year-old near Cardiff University as she walked home alone after a night out with friends on 20 September. The prosecution at Newport Crown Court has alleged she was so drunk she could not have consented to sex. The defendant, who is Romanian and lives in Cardiff, denies rape. The court heard the woman lost her friends during her night out and started to walk home along Greyfriars Road, under an underpass by City Hall and then along Museum Avenue at about 02:00 GMT. It was here she was approached by the defendant and the alleged rape happened behind a bush. Claire Pickthall, prosecuting, told the jury the victim was "so drunk she can't remember the incident happening. She can't even remember him having sex with her". It was this intoxication, she said, that meant she was not in any state to consent. "The actions in these circumstances amount to rape," Ms Pickthall said. "He was

original:
The walk-in service is aimed at reducing doctor appointments and to help reduce the over-use of antibiotics, NHS England said. It is hoped that the new approach will provide a more efficient and effective means for patients seeking treatment for minor ailments, potentially cutting down waiting times and easing the pressure on general practices.

The service is a strategic step in implementing the overarching goal of NHS England to manage antibiotic resistance, a growing health concern worldwide. Overuse of antibiotics has been linked to the emergence of resistant bacterial strains, posing a significant global health risk.

The walk-in service will be based in pharmacies across England, with trained practitioners providing on-the-spot advice and treatment without the requirement of an appointment. The list of ailments to be covered under the service includes sore throats, colds, and minor infections.

NHS England believes that this initiative will not only reduce the strain on GP surgeries and hospitals but also help in educating the public about the perils of overusing antibiotics. By integrating pharmacies more deeply into the healthcare

original:
The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, set at the height of the Cold War, is being adapted by the Oscar-winning writer of The Imitation Game, Graham Moore. The espionage thriller, originally a novel by John le Carré, will be making its transition into a gripping television drama. Moore, known for his ability to masterfully craft complex narratives, is set to bring a fresh perspective to the classic Cold War story.

The novel's protagonist, Alec Leamas, a hardworking British agent who is in the throes of the East-West conflict in Berlin, will be the focal point of this adaptation. The story's timeless themes of loyalty, betrayal, and human integrity are set to be explored in depth, promising a thrilling experience for viewers.

This adaptation is expected to bring a new generation of viewers closer to le Carré’s work, while also pleasing long-time fans with its faithful rendition of the novel’s atmospheric tension and intricate plot. The production date is yet to be announced,

original: They began their trip by travelling to the Seamus Heaney Homeplace Centre in Bellaghy, where they met members of the poet's family. The Royal couple will attend a series of engagements in Londonderry, Belfast and County Down during their visit. During their visit to Bellaghy, the Royal couple toured the visitors' centre. The village inspired many of Seamus Heaney's most memorable lines. Prince Charles has had a long interest in the Nobel prize-winning poet's work and met him on a number of occasions. After leaving Bellaghy, they met staff and patients at the North West Cancer Centre at Altnagelvin Hospital in Londonderry. On Tuesday evening they attended a musical gathering at Hillsborough Castle, in County Down. They are also expected to officially open a memorial garden to members of the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) who were killed while on duty. On Wednesday, the couple will begin an official visit in the Republic

original: The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway. The Â£1m project on land near Sanquhar was funded by the Duke of Buccleuch. It will be launched on Sunday with a performance by a cast of 30 dancers and musicians. The Crawick Artland Trust, which manages the site, has said it hopes to attract international visitors and boost business in Sanquhar, Kelloholm and Kirkconnel. The opening performance, which coincides with the Summer solstice, is called Oceanallover and it has been specially developed by artistic director Alex Rigg. He said: "Through conversations with Charles Jencks and with the Duke of Buccleuch and the local community, it is clear to me that my job is to present something which is interesting to look at in itself but allows other people to see the potential of the site for future events." The performance is likely to raise questions, rather than answer them, he said. "It's likely to be quite abstract at times
variant_1: The Crawick Multiverse, crafted by the famous artist Charles Jencks, was built using materials sourced from the Dumfries and Galloway site. This £1 million project on land near Sanquhar received funding from the Duke of Buccleuch. It will debut on Sunday with a show featuring 30 dancers and musicians. Managed by the Crawick Artland Trust, the site aims to draw international visitors and stimulate business in Sanquhar, Kelloholm, and Kirkconnel. The opening act, named Oceanallover, coincides with the Summer solstice and was specially created by artistic director Alex Rigg. He stated, "After discussions with Charles Jencks, the Duke of Buccleuch, and the local community, my role is to present something visually engaging that also reveals the site's potential for future events." The performance is expected to provoke questions rather than provide answers, and it may be quite abstract at times.

original: The changes would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house, signalling a significant shift from Japan's post-war pacifism and marking a milestone in its military normalization. The bill, if approved by the upper house, would extend Japan's military options by ending a ban on exercising collective self-defense, or aiding an ally under attack. While supporters argue that it is crucial for Japan to strengthen its role in global security amid growing regional threats, the move has triggered widespread protests from citizens and constitutional scholars who contend it violates Japan's constitution and could potentially embroil the country in U.S.-led conflicts around the globe. This legislation is a reflection of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push for Japan to take on a more assertive military posture, a stance that has raised eyebrows within the international community.
variant_1: Japanese troops would be permitted to engage in combat overseas for the first time since World War II under these changes.
variant_2: The legislation, already approved by Japan's lower house, marks a major departure from the country's post-war pacifist stance and represents a key step toward military normalization.
variant_3: If the upper house passes the bill, Japan would be able to exercise collective self-defense, allowing it to assist allies under attack, thereby broadening its military capabilities.
variant_4: Proponents claim that strengthening Japan's role in global security is essential given increasing regional threats, while opponents argue the law breaches the constitution and risks involving Japan in U.S.-led conflicts worldwide.
variant_5: The bill reflects Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to adopt a more assertive military policy, a move that has drawn concern internationally.
variant_6: For the first time since World War II, Japanese forces could fight abroad due to these legislative changes.
variant_7: Passing the bill in the lower house signals a significant shift away from Japan's post-war pacifism and toward military normalization.
variant_8: Approval by the upper house would lift the ban on collective self-defense, enabling Japan to support allies under attack and expand its military options.
variant_9: Supporters emphasize the necessity of Japan playing a stronger role in global security amid rising regional dangers, while critics warn it violates the constitution and risks entanglement in global conflicts led by the U.S.
variant_10: This legislation embodies Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push for Japan to adopt a more proactive military stance, which has raised concerns within the international community.

original: The 31-year-old tweeted she was turned away from a black cab and told to "find an immigrant" to give her a ride. The alleged altercation comes after she apologised "on behalf of my country" over squalid conditions at the Jungle camp in Calais. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association said it condemned abusive behaviour. The singer wrote on Twitter: "Just tried to get in a black cab with my kids. The driver looked at me and said 'find an immigrant to drive you you stupid tart'." She went on to add: "Having lived a life of privilege, that interaction has given me a tiny glimpse of what it feels like to be discriminated against." Her claims have been questioned by some. One Twitter user said it "definitely didn't happen", while another asked her to reveal the taxi's registration plate. Taibu, 32, played 28 Test matches and 150 one-day internationals for Zimbabwe prior to retiring in 2012. "When he explained who he was, it was like meeting a legend in person," said young fan, Tinashe Moyo, who had never had the chance to see the wicketkeeper-batsman play in his prime. 

In his ten-year career, Taibu was renowned for his technical proficiency, agility behind the stumps, and captaincy. His retirement shocked many, as he was still at the peak of his prowess, but he cited personal and family reasons for his decision.

Since hanging up his cricket pads, Taibu has devoted his time to promoting and developing the sport at grassroots level in African communities. Many young athletes have benefited from his mentorship and training, and his dedication to giving back to the sport has been lauded by sporting and community figures alike.

The were 37 crimes recorded in Cromer over the weekend - including the rape of a teenager - with residents linking them to a group of travellers. The weekend saw an alarming total of 37 crimes recorded in Cromer, including a horrifying incident of a teenage girl being raped. Local residents believe the crimes are linked to a group of travellers who moved into the area recently.

The spate of incidents began on Friday night, with reports of thefts, disturbances, and disorderly behaviour. But it was the sexual assault on the teenager that has left the community in shock and fear. Local authorities are treating the incident with utmost severity and have launched a full-scale investigation.

The police are conducting regular patrols and checks in the area to ensure residents' safety. Authorities have also called for calm and urged residents not to take matters into their own hands, assuring them that every possible step is being taken to bring the culprits to justice.

Residents have been asked to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activities to the police. The incidents have sparked a debate about the need for better security measures in the seaside town.

"It's been a massive showcase for so much that's positive, strong and good about Wales," he said. Mr Crabb stated the relationship between the Welsh people and their nation has been enriched by the recent achievements in the fields of sports, arts, and culture.

According to him, the recent victories of the national rugby team on the global stage have been a source of tremendous pride and unity. He highlighted the success of Welsh actors and singers on international platforms, reinforcing the unique Welsh identity and culture. Furthermore, he praised the remarkable work done by Welsh businesses, contributing to not only the national economy but also creating a noticeable impact globally.

"The world has seen the very best of Wales and it's only the beginning," he said, expressing his optimism about the future. Mr Crabb emphasized the importance of the ongoing efforts to promote Welsh language and culture, stating that Wales is ready to contribute more to the world and make its mark.

There are now almost half a million votes to send the singer to the secretive communist nation. The contest, which ends at 0600 on 7 July, saw North Korea move from 24th to 1st place in less than two days. Many of the votes are thought to originate from imageboard website 4chan, which has built a reputation for triggering online viral campaigns. The voting site is not endorsed by Mr Bieber's record label. original:
But he fancied his video game skills and entered Nissan's GT Academy competition while on a gap year. After beating 90,000 other gamers from across the globe, the prodigious talent, Joe Smith, stepped into the spotlight. 

Many scoffed at the idea of a video gamer transitioning into a professional race car driver, but Smith proved them wrong. The 23-year-old demonstrated his skill set was not confined to virtual competitions. His tenacity, determination, and an uncanny knack for strategic gameplay led him to outpace his competitors and clinch the championship. 

Smith's incredible journey from a casual gamer to a professional racer has not only redefined traditional pathways into motorsports but also validated the place of e-sports in mainstream competition. His victory at the GT Academy has set a precedent, proving that passion, dedication, and skill can overcome traditional barriers. This triumph signifies a victory for all e-sports enthusiasts and a game-changing moment for the world of competitive racing.

original: These beautiful pictures are the first ever taken of a wild lioness nursing a cub from a different species - an extremely rare event. The pair were spotted by Joop Van Der Linde, a guest at Ndutu Safari Lodge in Tanzania's Ngorongoro Conservation Area. The scene is the Serengeti; the attentive mother, five-year-old Nosikitok. The lioness has a GPS collar fitted by Kope Lion, a conservation NGO, and three young cubs of her own - born around the 27-28 June. Dr Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer for Panthera, a global wild cat conservation organisation which supports Kope Lion, told the BBC the incident was "truly unique". "It's not something that I'm aware has ever happened before between large cats like this," he said. "We know there are cases where lionesses will adopt other lion cubs... But this is unprecedented. "I know of no other case - between any large cat, for that matter - where the

original:
The latest Markit Report on Jobs for Scotland found sharp rises in permanent and temporary job placements in April. Growth in temporary staff demand was also at its highest rate since December 2018, providing positive signals about the Scottish job market. 

The report indicates an accelerated increase in permanent staff appointments, and recruiters signaled a strong upturn in short-term roles. This surge is particularly notable after the economic slowdown caused by the pandemic. The demand for workers is increasing in various sectors, with IT & Computing leading the way in permanent staff demand, whereas Nursing/Medical/Care topped the demand for temporary staff.

Moreover, the availability of candidates for permanent roles deteriorated at a steep and accelerated rate, leading to a surge in starting salaries. Meanwhile, temp wages also grew at a faster pace. 

This data suggests that Scotland's job market is bouncing back robustly, with increasing demand for both permanent and temporary staff and growing wages, bringing a much-needed boost to the Scottish economy.

original: An official has told an assembly committee that Cardiff Aviation, which has leased a hangar at St Athan from the administration since 2012, has not paid rent for the last three years. The Vale of Glamorgan-based maintenance and repair firm, co-owned by Iron Maiden singer Bruce Dickinson, faces financial difficulties since 2019, leading to delayed rent payments. The official disclosed that the outstanding rent totals an estimated £500,000. The revelation has sparked a significant concern among the assembly members over the administration's measures to ensure the collection of due payments. The company's failure to pay rent has put additional financial pressure on St Athan, already struggling due to the economic impact of the pandemic. Assembly members are now urging the administration to take immediate action to recoup the lost funds. Cardiff Aviation is yet to comment on the matter. This situation has highlighted the need for stricter enforcement of lease agreements to protect public finances.

original: Transport for London (TfL) is to consult on plans to demand a new English language test, a map-reading assessment, a fixed landline and the chance to book seven days in advance. Uber said: "If adopted these [rules] would mean an end to the Uber people know and love." Black cab drivers have argued regulations need to be tightened. There has been growing pressure on city legislators, most recently when cab drivers protested outside City Hall. The Uber app connects customers and nearby drivers using GPS technology and gives an estimate of the fare. It generally charges lower fares than traditional firms and drivers rely on technology for navigation. Transactions are cashless using pre-registered bank details. TfL says the consultation seeks to "raise standards across the industry" following an "exponential" growth in the private hire industry and technology. Uber said it was a deliberate target and if the proposals went ahead they would raise prices and increase congestion in London. Gareth Mead, from Uber, said: "If you think that this is supposed to be a public consultation, well I think the public are not at the

There has been increasing pressure on city legislators, especially after cab drivers protested outside City Hall. The Uber app connects customers with nearby drivers via GPS and provides fare estimates. It usually charges less than traditional taxi firms, with drivers relying on technology for navigation. Transactions are cashless, using pre-registered bank details. TfL says the consultation aims to "raise standards across the industry" following rapid growth in private hire and technology. Uber claims it is being deliberately targeted and that the proposals would increase fares and congestion in London. Gareth Mead from Uber said, "If this is a public consultation, the public is not being heard."

Root's first Test match as England skipper is against South Africa at Lord's beginning on 7 July. The 26-year-old has stepped up from vice-captain, with Durham all-rounder Stokes, 25, filling the role as his deputy. variant_1: Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been appointed as the new Test captain following Alastair Cook's resignation after more than four years leading the team. "We aim to win but also want to play in a way that attracts fans," said Stokes. Root's debut as England's Test skipper will be against South Africa at Lord's starting 7 July. The 26-year-old has been promoted from vice-captain, with Durham all-rounder Stokes, 25, taking over as his deputy. "Test cricket is the highest level, and we want to rekindle people's passion for it," Stokes added. Reflecting on his new vice-captain role, he said: "My focus is always on winning, and this position won't change who I am as a player or person. "I want to be involved in every part of the game, whether it's scoring the winning runs or taking the last wicket. I've always wanted to be at the heart of the action. "As vice-captain, I will bring mental strength and support."

original:
Until now, Google Assistant had only been available on the firm's own Pixel phones. The service, akin to Siri on iPhones, allows users to interact with their devices using voice commands, delivering a hands-free, convenient experience. However, in a bid to make this feature more accessible, Google announced recently that it will be expanding the availability of Google Assistant to a wider range of smartphones.

This strategic move aims to compete directly with Apple's Siri and Amazon's Alexa, offering users of other Android devices the same high-quality, intelligent voice-controlled virtual assistant. This expansion will enable more users to enjoy the benefits of Google Assistant, such as setting reminders, sending texts, or asking for directions, all by just using their voice. 

This initiative places Google at the forefront of the drive to make technology more intuitive and user-friendly. By democratizing this cutting-edge technology, Google is not only reinforcing its commitment to innovation but also to inclusivity, ensuring all Android users can enjoy the benefits of a virtual assistant.

Recently, Google announced plans to extend Google Assistant to a broader range of smartphones to increase accessibility.

original: The H3 project combines back office services at four police, fire and council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, to save up to £5m a year. The Police Federation said payroll mistakes were among a "catalogue of errors" since H3 began in 2014. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) said the investment would deliver improvements by May. A report to PCC Michael Lane said H3 had caused problems with recruitment and the management of staff sickness, as well as "weighing down" police officers with "back office processes which restrict their effectiveness". In February 2016, 1,300 officers received the wrong pay, while some allowances were wrongly calculated in March. In 2015, the BBC learned that payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers had trebled. under the new system. Hampshire Police Federation chairman John Apter said the system had been "poorly conceived, implemented and delivered". "On paper it looked great but in reality it was shambolic and... the fall-out... has been nothing short of
variant_1: The H3 initiative merges back office operations across four police, fire, and council bodies in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, aiming to save up to £5 million annually. Since its launch in 2014, the Police Federation has reported payroll errors among a series of mistakes. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) promised improvements by May following investment. A report to PCC Michael Lane highlighted issues with recruitment, staff sickness management, and burdensome back office tasks limiting police effectiveness. In February 2016, 1,300 officers were paid incorrectly, and some allowances were miscalculated in March. In 2015, the BBC found that payment delays to Hampshire County Council suppliers had tripled under the new system. John Apter, chairman of Hampshire Police Federation, criticized the system as poorly designed, implemented, and delivered, calling it shambolic despite its promising appearance on paper.

The holders, who also won the trophy in 2013, bowed out in the group stage despite six wins in 14 games. Promotion in the County Championship may have softened the blow, but it was a disappointing end to their campaign in the tournament. The holders, who also won the trophy in 2013, bowed out in the group stage despite six wins in 14 games. Promotion in the County Championship may have softened the blow for the club, but it was a bitter pill to swallow for the fans who had high hopes for a repeat victory.

The team started the season on a high note, but inconsistency and injuries took their toll as the tournament progressed. The holders won six of their first eight matches, but a string of four consecutive losses saw them lose their grip on the coveted trophy. Despite a late resurgence, they failed to make it past the group stage.

original:
Ben Butler met a psychologist in 2004 after assaulting a man in a nightclub. Dr Tim Green wrote in his report that Mr Butler found it "difficult to control his anger", which was alarmingly indicative of his pattern of violent behavior. This observation has now resurfaced after Butler was convicted of further violent crimes, highlighting a disappointing failure of the legal and therapeutic systems in managing and averting such cases.

Butler's psychological assessment, made public after recent legal proceedings, underscored the warning signs that were seemingly overlooked. His inability to manage his angry reactions, which led to acts of violence, was not adequately addressed nor were preventive measures put in place.

The case of Ben Butler exposes a larger problem in the system where insufficient attention is given to repeated offenders exhibiting signs of systemic violence. It challenges the efficacy of our rehabilitative measures and prompts a call for more proactive action in managing violent individuals. The system's ability to protect citizens from repeat offenders remains under scrutiny.

original:
Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) said the force had "fragile" staffing levels and needed to "implement more robust human resource strategies."

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) has issued a stark warning about frailty in police staffing levels, stating that the force currently operates with "fragile" staffing levels and needs to "implement more robust human resource strategies." This recent assessment has thrown light on the intensifying pressure faced by law enforcement agencies around the country, which are grappling with budget cuts and rising crime rates.

The Inspectorate called for immediate action to address the issue, suggesting that workforce planning and recruitment efforts are not keeping pace with the departure or retirement of experienced staff. HMIC emphasized that higher quality leadership and management, coupled with the implementation of a more strategic workforce plan, can help to stave off the staffing crisis.

Public safety is potentially at risk if these concerns are not addressed promptly. The HMIC's findings serve as an urgent call to action for the police forces to bolster their ranks and ensure the public's trust in their ability to maintain law and order.

original:
Gene Palmer is the second prison worker detained over the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with aiding the escape. The prisoners, Richard Matt and David Sweat, were both serving lengthy sentences at the Clinton Correctional Facility.

Gene Palmer is the second prison worker detained over the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with aiding the escape, having allegedly provided the prisoners with tools hidden inside meat. Palmer is believed to have unknowingly assisted in the escape, also under Mitchell's manipulation.

The prisoners, Richard Matt and David Sweat, have led authorities on a wild goose chase since their daring getaway. Both were serving sentences for murder. Their escape has triggered a massive manhunt, causing widespread fear and alarm across the region.

Palmer's arrest marks a new turn in an already complex investigation. His lawyer stated he will plead not guilty to the alleged charges, including promoting prison contraband and tampering with evidence.

As the drama continues to unfold, questions loom regarding the security and supervision of prisons. The incident has ignited a nationwide debate on the need for reform in the prison system and the responsibility of prison staff in ensuring the public's

original: Palmer expects to be fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for the rule breach during Champions Day. "It was an oversight," Palmer told BBC Sport. "The wrong kit box was left in the lorry and taken to the stables." The Newmarket-based trainer saw Galilieo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Horses are only allowed to receive hay-feed or water before a race, but other substances such as electrolytes are permitted post-race. Employees of Palmer and fellow trainers, Francois Rohaut and and Jean-Claude Rouget, as well as the trainers themselves, were interviewed by stewards following a report by the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer is yet to hear what punishment the BHA will hand down. "I imagine there will be a routine fine for a rule that's been broken," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. "There's no suggestion that anyone was trying to seek an advantage or cheat. It's simply what the rule says. The rules are the rules and you need to stick to them."

"The incorrect kit box was left in the lorry and brought to the stables." The Newmarket-based trainer watched Galileo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Horses are only permitted to have hay-feed or water before a race, but substances like electrolytes are allowed after the race. Palmer's staff, along with those of trainers Francois Rohaut and Jean-Claude Rouget, and the trainers themselves, were questioned by stewards following a report from the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer has not yet been informed of the penalty from the BHA. "I expect a standard fine for breaking the rule," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. "There is no indication anyone tried to gain an unfair advantage or cheat. The rules are clear and must be followed."

original: The child, who was under 13, needed medical treatment following the attack by Ajay Jetha last year. A probation report three months earlier warned he might snatch a child "at any time", Leicester Crown Court heard. Jetha, 32, was told he must serve at least 11 years. Updates on this story and more from Leicestershire He previously admitted some offences relating to last year's attack but on Monday changed his plea to guilty to all 10 charges relating to the boy, known only as Child A, which included photographing his assault. He also admitted a further 10 unconnected child sex offences. During the sentencing hearing on Tuesday, it was revealed just three months before the brutal assault in Leicester a Probation Service report said "he could at any time take a child off the street". Speaking after the hearing, Lawrence English, from the Crown Prosecution Service, said: "The police were obviously aware of that [report]

He had previously admitted some offenses related to the attack but on Monday pleaded guilty to all 10 charges involving the boy, known as Child A, including photographing the assault. He also admitted to 10 unrelated child sex offenses. During sentencing on Tuesday, it was revealed that a Probation Service report from three months before the assault stated "he could at any time take a child off the street." Lawrence English from the Crown Prosecution Service said after the hearing, "The police were obviously aware of that [report]."

original:
Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to lead the global efforts in climate finance. 

Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to leverage its economic strength and technological prowess to drive investment in sustainable initiatives worldwide. 

"Germany is in a unique position to steer global markets towards a greener future. This could bring not only environmental benefits but also economic gains, both for Germany and for the emerging countries," Mr Carney said. 

Highlighting the potential of green technology to create jobs and drive economic growth, Carney encouraged German businesses and financial institutions to invest in renewable energy and sustainable infrastructure projects in developing countries. He noted the importance of these investments in achieving the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

Carney's message underscores the central role of finance in tackling climate change and promoting sustainable development. It is a call for Germany, Europe's largest economy, to step up and lead the way in the global green finance movement.

Violence in the country began last April, when President Pierre Nkurunziza announced he would seek a third term. At least 439 people have died and 240,000 have fled abroad, the UN says. African Union (AU) leaders are due to discuss the crisis in Burundi at a summit in Ethiopia. They want Mr Nkurunziza to accept peacekeeping troops to prevent Burundi sliding into ethnic conflict, but analysts say he is unlikely to agree. Burundi on the brink Tit-for-tat killings spread fear Burundi's football-playing president Presidents who cling to power Amnesty says satellite images show disturbed earth at sites in the Buringa area on the edge of the capital Bujumbura that are consistent with witness reports. He threatened to quit the Premier League club within 24 hours if the name change bid failed, and the Football Association turned it down in April. True to his word, the owner has now officially stepped down, leaving the fans and players in a state of shock.

The controversial bid to change the historic club's name to something more modern was met with significant pushback from the loyal fanbase. The owner argued that a name change would attract new fans and bring in additional revenue, but traditionalists were adamant that the club's identity was not for sale.

Since the Football Association's decision, tension has been growing within the club. The owner's resignation leaves the club in an uncertain position. Fans are concerned about the future and the potential for financial instability.

original:
Erika Murray, 31, was arrested on Thursday night after a neighbour alerted police over the safety of other children living at the house. Detectives swiftly responded to the call, arriving at the residence to initiate investigation. 

Upon arriving, officers found conditions to be severely neglectful and hazardous. The children present, all under the age of 10, were immediately taken into protective custody due to the apparent immediate threats to their wellbeing. 

While details surrounding the case remain to be fully disclosed, preliminary reports indicate that the children lived amidst squalor, with insufficient food and sanitation. Authorities express their deep concern over the long-term physical and psychological health of the affected children. 

Charged with multiple counts of child endangerment, Murray is set to face a judge early next week. As the investigation continues, authorities are working diligently to ensure the safety and welfare of the children involved. More updates will be provided as this heartbreaking story unfolds.

"We wanted to be in a position going into the last five games where we had something to play for, and we have," Ripley told BBC Radio Northampton. "We'll be pushing hard to get ourselves in there with maybe two games to go, one game to go. "I'm just looking forward to seeing us get stuck in and who knows, it could still be a pretty special season." original: Mark Footitt took 3-52 as the visitors lost five wickets before lunch while Sam Curran dismissed England opener Haseeb Hameed for a second-ball duck. But Clark's 108 not out from 133 balls and Shivnarine Chanderpaul's steady 85 not out rebuilt the visitor's innings. Clark reached his century with a huge pulled six shortly before the close. Retired West Indies international Chanderpaul put on 55 with Ryan McLaren, calming the innings after the early wickets, before the 42-year-old was joined by Clark when Gareth Batty dismissed McLaren. The pair then shared an unbeaten partnership of 172 with Clark - batting at eight in the order - soon overtaking Chanderpaul's score, beating him to his half-century. The game was halted due to bad light in the evening session but that did nothing to halt Clark's progress. In total the 26-year-old - whose previous high score was 84 not out - hit 17 fours and three sixes in his innings. The change in fortunes for Lancashire was even more remarkable given they

original: The party's election manifesto said a funding floor would only be introduced after a referendum was called. The St David's Day Agreement had said the vote would be an "expectation", and Labour Welsh ministers oppose a referendum before a funding deal. Labour accused the Tories of trying to hold them "over a barrel". The manifesto states the Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to protect Welsh relative funding and provide certainty for the Welsh Government to plan for the future, once it has called a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next Parliament". But a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman told BBC Wales: "The St David's Day commitment we made to introduce a funding floor for Wales is firm and clear, and work is already underway at the Treasury and the Wales Office to bring this floor forward. "The funding floor for Wales is not contingent on an income tax referendum. Our UK manifesto makes clear our expectation that the Welsh Assembly will hold a referendum on income tax raising powers early in the next
variant_1: The party's election manifesto stated that a funding floor would only be implemented after a referendum was held. The St David's Day Agreement described the vote as an "expectation," and Welsh Labour ministers oppose holding a referendum before securing a funding deal. Labour accused the Tories of trying to pressure them unfairly. The manifesto says the Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to safeguard Welsh relative funding and provide certainty for the Welsh Government's future planning, once a referendum on Income Tax powers is called in the next Parliament." However, a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman told BBC Wales that the commitment to introduce a funding floor is firm and work is already underway at the Treasury and Wales Office. She added that the funding floor is not dependent on an income tax referendum, and the UK manifesto expects the Welsh Assembly to hold a referendum on income tax powers early in the next term.

original: Tear gas and live bullets were fired to drive back the mainly Shia Muslim crowds, as they protested against corruption and security failures. Officials imposed a curfew in the Iraqi capital, which has now been lifted. It was the second time this month that protesters had managed to break into the city's government area. Shia Muslim cleric Moqtada Sadr condemned the use of force, and voiced support for the demonstrators' "peaceful [and] spontaneous revolt". At least 50 demonstrators are said to have been wounded. The protesters accuse the government of neglecting much-needed reforms, as it struggles with its campaign against the so-called Islamic State group (IS) and declining oil revenues. The Sunni jihadist group controls parts of western and northern Iraq and has been behind a wave of recent attacks that have left dozens killed. Some demonstrators managed to break into the prime minister's office and parliament. Baghdad's Green Zone houses the parliament, key government buildings and many foreign embassies. The authorities later said they had completely regained control of the area and the protesters had withdrawn. The Shia cleric and his militia group, the Mehdi Army, gained prominence after the US-led invasion
variant_1: Tear gas and live ammunition were used to disperse predominantly Shia Muslim protesters who were demonstrating against corruption and security lapses. A curfew was enforced in Baghdad but has since been lifted. This marked the second occasion this month that protesters breached the city's government district. Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr criticized the violent response and expressed support for the demonstrators' peaceful and spontaneous uprising. Reports indicate at least 50 protesters were injured. The demonstrators blame the government for failing to implement essential reforms amid its fight against the Islamic State group and falling oil revenues. The Sunni extremist group controls parts of western and northern Iraq and has carried out recent deadly attacks. Some protesters infiltrated the prime minister's office and parliament. Baghdad's Green Zone, home to parliament, key government offices, and foreign embassies, was later fully secured by authorities after protesters withdrew. Moqtada Sadr and his militia, the Mehdi Army, rose to prominence following the US-led invasion.

The Financial Conduct Authority said these customers were profitable for card providers and so there were few incentives for the firms to intervene. It said customers should be wary and take necessary precautions to safeguard their financial interests. This follows from a recent study on the business practices of card providers, which revealed that their intervention in the financial decisions of profitable customers is minimal, often leading to unchecked spending. 

The FCA urged consumers to be more pro-active about their financial decisions, and not to rely solely on card companies for advice or intervention. It also recommended that customers regularly review their credit card usage and take advantage of financial tools and resources to manage their spending effectively.

Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, spun a remarkable tale about a band of alien frogs that had taken over his town, causing pandemonium as they croaked the national anthem out of tune at all hours. North, 24, landed on his head after a high tackle from Adam Thompstone in his side's 19-11 defeat against Leicester Tigers on Saturday. The incident sparked major concern for the player's health as North remained motionless on the pitch for several minutes before being stretchered off.

Medical staff were quick to tend to the rugby star, with early reports suggesting that he may have suffered a concussion. The incident has reignited debates about player safety in rugby, with some calling for stricter enforcement of high-tackle rules.

The Rugby Football Union, the sport's governing body, has announced that it will conduct an immediate review into the incident. 

North's team, Northampton Saints, issued a statement expressing their concern for the player's well-being and promising to support him throughout his recovery. North has a history of concussions, which adds to the collective worry surrounding his recent injury.

This incident underscores the inherent risks of contact sports and calls for a renewed focus on player safety.

OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to their findings, the creativity and linguistic skill displayed by these budding authors were nothing short of remarkable. 

The stories covered a range of themes, reflecting the concerns, dreams, and fascinations of children across the UK. Climate change, pollution, and animal extinction emerged as prevalent issues, indicating the young participants’ acute awareness of environmental challenges. The narratives also explored themes of adventure, friendship, and family, demonstrating children's understanding of complex emotional dynamics.

The analysis revealed a striking use of vocabulary, with words like 'pandemic,' 'lockdown,' and 'virus' prominent, reflecting the influence of the Covid-19 crisis on children's lives. Additionally, an increase in the use of technology-related words was observed.

original: The deal unveiled by Russia on Thursday to set up four "de-escalation zones" is backed by Turkey and Iran. But the main Syrian opposition grouping says it has little faith in the deal. Elsewhere in Syria, activists say government aircraft have hit central Hama province, and there are reports of shelling and gunfire in other parts. The opposition High Negotiations Committee (HNC), said on Friday the safe zones plan lacked "safeguards and compliance mechanisms". It also said it did not accept Iran as a guarantor of the deal. The UN special envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, told the BBC the agreement was important because it was being implemented by three countries who could make it work. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) said Syrian fighter jets on Saturday bombed rebel positions in Hama. A rebel commander confirmed that fighting had broken out after midnight, Reuters reports. The Syrian military have so far not commented on the issue. UN special envoy Staffan de Mistura told the BBC the agreement was important because it was being implemented by three countries capable of enforcing it. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) said Syrian jets bombed rebel positions in Hama on Saturday. A rebel commander confirmed fighting broke out after midnight, Reuters reports. Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. The young duo's decision to withdraw from the international cricket circuit came as a surprise to many fans and critics alike. Abbott, known for his steely consistency, and Rossouw, renowned for his tenacity at the crease, have been significant contributors to their national teams. 

The decision to retire early is understood to be a personal choice for both players, motivated by a desire to focus on their domestic careers. Their retirement has sparked a fresh debate on the increasing demands of international cricket on players' physical and mental health.

However, their departure from the international scene does not mean a complete disappearance from the cricket field. Both players plan to continue playing at the domestic level, bringing their skills and experience to benefit their local teams. As cricket enthusiasts bid farewell to the international careers of these talented players, they look forward to witnessing their continued contributions to the sport.

original: The launch of what was supposed to be its flagship model has turned into a fiasco for the world's largest smartphone maker. As the South Korean company scrambles to contain the crisis, we look back at the developments so far: 2 August: Samsung unveils its latest flagship model Galaxy Note 7 amid great fanfare in New York. The phone is packed with new features like an iris scanner. The initial response is good and expectations high. It's seen as Samsung's big rival to the upcoming iPhone 7. 19 August: Sales start in 10 markets, including South Korea and the United States. European markets are scheduled for October. 24 August: The first report of a Note 7 device "exploding" appear in the news. It isn't long before there are more incidents with users posting pictures and videos of what they say are their phones overheating, exploding or catching fire. 2 September: Samsung announces a voluntary global recall of some 2.5 million Note 7 phones, citing faulty batteries. The company
variant_1: The launch of what was intended to be its flagship model has turned into a disaster for the world's largest smartphone manufacturer. As the South Korean firm rushes to manage the crisis, we review the events so far: On 2 August, Samsung introduced its newest flagship, the Galaxy Note 7, with much fanfare in New York. The phone featured new technologies like an iris scanner. Initial reactions were positive and expectations high, positioning it as Samsung's main competitor to the forthcoming iPhone 7. On 19 August, sales began in 10 countries, including South Korea and the US, with European launches planned for October. On 24 August, the first news of a Note 7 device "exploding" emerged. Soon after, more incidents surfaced with users sharing images and videos of phones overheating, exploding, or catching fire. On 2 September, Samsung announced a voluntary global recall of approximately 2.5 million Note 7 units due to defective batteries.
variant_2: What was supposed to be the flagship launch for the world's largest smartphone maker has turned into a fiasco. The phone included features like an iris scanner, and initial feedback was positive with high expectations, seen as a strong competitor to the upcoming iPhone 7. Sales began on 19 August in 10 markets including South Korea and the US, with Europe set for October. On 24 August, reports surfaced of Note 7 devices "exploding," followed by more incidents with users posting photos and videos of phones overheating, exploding, or catching fire.
